awd_titl_txt: Combinatorial State Sums and Interval Flag Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project addresses questions in algebraic combinatorics and algebraic geometry, areas of mathematics concerned with the description of symmetry and with the solution of multivariate polynomial equations.  The project involves the study of "state sums" -- a catchall term from statistical mechanics to describe certain sums of products (typically of polynomials) -- and the study of topological quantum field theory, which arose in physics and has turned out to have connections to several areas of modern mathematics. Many important quantities in algebraic combinatorics can be computed as state sums; these are often sums over all the labelings of a quadrangulated surface with compatible tiles, like assembling a jigsaw puzzle. The remarkable fact is that these totals are frequently independent of the quadrangulation, suggesting that they may have some more fundamental definition. This project investigates a source from topological quantum field theory that might unify these state sum results, while suggesting ways to probe them more deeply. Specifically, changing a quadrangulation on a surface relates to evolving it through space, which suggests exploring both higher- and lower-dimensional analogues. This program has many subprojects suitable for graduate students in mathematics and statistical mechanics, who will be involved in the research.

This research program comprises two projects. The first project uses inspiration from quantum field theory and geometric representation theory in an endeavor to elucidate polynomial formulae arising in algebraic combinatorics.  Formulae for interesting polynomials often take the form of sums of products of linear polynomials. For example, the "Schubert polynomial" associated to a permutation can be written as a sum over certain 2-d diagrams for the permutation. The project will look more deeply into these polynomial formulae, in two steps. The first step is to see a polynomial as a matrix coefficient inside a time-evolution operator in a (1+1)-dimensional quantum field theory. Since long-time-evolution is a composite of many short-time evolutions, the matrix might be expressed as a product of simpler matrices, giving exactly the sum over products. The second step is to regard the Hilbert spaces of these quantum field theories as homology groups of certain algebraic varieties, after the manner of geometric representation theory. This would naturally imply some commutation properties of these matrices, such as the Yang-Baxter equation.  The second project aims to develop a generalization of Schubert calculus to chains of linear subspaces.

por.por_cntn:
Two blue points in space determine a red line, but how many red lines in space touch four generically chosen blue lines? This nontrivial problem (whose answer is 2) is the first interesting example of "Schubert calculus", which concerns the number of linear solutions to linear intersection problems, in any dimension. (Of course most problems one wants to solve in mathematics, other sciences, and engineering are not linear, but often one can show that if a linearized version of a problem has no solutions, then neither will the original nonlinear problem.) 
 There have been many formulae proven for many special cases of this sort of linear problem, but the most powerful ones (answering the most general cases) counted diagrams that looked intriguingly like the "scattering diagrams" from particle physics. The principal goals of this project were (1) to get to the bottom of this apparent connection and (2) see if old results from physics could be imported into and exploited in Schubert calculus to answer new problems. Both are now quite satisfactorily achieved. 
 To be a bit more concrete, we start with a very solved problem: counting k-planes in n-space satisfying a list of intersection conditions ("V intersects this 5-plane W in at least dimension 3" and the like). Schubert in the 19th century had a list of techniques that could in principle solve any of these, and making his process rigorous was the subject of the 15th problem in Hilbert's famous list of open math problems for the 20th century. It wasn't until the 1930s that a manifestly positive formula (rather than an alternating sum) was proposed, and that formula was only proven in the 1970s. 
 The holy grail of the subject is to count, instead of single k-planes, "flags" consisiting of a 1-plane inside a 2-plane inside ... inside n-space. The weird situation is that we have alternating-sum formulae, so any single answer is easily computed, but we have no effective way in advance to know whether the number is zero or positive except to do the whole sum. 
 One thing we were able to do, in connecting to scattering diagrams, was show that the right measure of complexity is the number of steps in the flag, where e.g. the "2-step" problem concerns pairs {j-plane < k-plane}. We gave a new and much cleaner proof of the PI's conjecture from 1999 (proven in 2014) for 2-step problems, proved a rule for the previously unsolved 3-step, and showed why 4-step is likely the end of the line for this technology (where it can be applied, but alas, does not give a manifestly positive rule). 
 This work has been widely disseminated in many conference talks and a topics course, and the PI is writing a book on the subject. It has spawned multiple side projects, two so far of which will be the subject of PhD theses. The diagrams themselves, and the linear intersection problems, are simple enough to explain to undergraduates and even earlier. The episode https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U8sq3BplCfI of PBS' Infinite Series, on earlier work of the PI in this direction, has been viewed 130K times.
